resources.string: Please enter your User ID (as listed in the letter that you received with this tablet).

The following are a series of cognitive tasks, several of which are the versions of the tasks you completed in the original Project Talent study.

 	 • Read the instructions for each task carefully.
 	 • Do the best you can. If you are unsure of the right answer, pick the one you think is the best.
 	 • If a task includes multiple-choice questions, select only one answer.
 	 • There is only one right answer for each question.

 Press the NEXT button to begin the first task.
What is your current marital status?
LIVING WITH PARTNER AS IF MARRIED
Are you living in a nursing home or other health care facility?
Do you consider yourself to be retired?
You told us that you are retired. Some people who are retired do still work for pay. In terms of your current employment situation, are you currently doing any work for pay?
In terms of your current employment situation, are you currently doing any work for pay?
On your current (main) job, do you work for someone else, are you self-employed, or what?
On your current (main) job, approximately how many hours do you work each week?

Thinking about work in general and not just your present situation, what do you think the chances are that you will be doing any work for pay after you reach age 62? Please answer on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 means \'surely won\'t happen\' and 10 means \'surely will happen.\'

Thinking about work in general and not just your present situation, what do you think the chances are that you will be doing any work for pay after you reach age 65? Please answer on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 means \'surely won\'t happen\' and 10 means \'surely will happen.\'

Thinking about work in general and not just your present situation, what do you think the chances are that you will be doing any work for pay after you reach age 70? Please answer on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 means \'surely won\'t happen\' and 10 means \'surely will happen.\'

Thinking about work in general and not just your present situation, what do you think the chances are that you will be working for pay again at any point in the future? Please answer on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 means \'surely won\'t happen\' and 10 means \'surely will happen.\'
The purpose of the next set of questions is to identify any problems you may experience due to any hearing loss. If you use a hearing aid, please answer the way you hear with the hearing aid.
Does a hearing problem cause you to feel embarrassed when meeting new people?
Does a hearing problem cause you to feel frustrated when talking to members of your family?
Do you have difficulty hearing when someone speaks in a whisper?
Do you feel handicapped by a hearing problem?
Does a hearing problem cause you difficulty when visiting friends, relatives or neighbors?
Does a hearing problem cause you to attend religious services less often than you would like?
Does a hearing problem cause you to have arguments with family members?
Does a hearing problem cause you difficulty when listening to a TV or radio?
Do you feel that any difficulty with your hearing limits or hampers your personal or social life?
Does a hearing problem cause you difficulty when in a restaurant with relatives or friends?
Do you ever wear a hearing aid?
Is your hearing excellent, very good, good, fair, or poor using a hearing aid as usual?
Is your hearing excellent, very good, good, fair, or poor?
Is your eyesight excellent, very good, good, fair, or poor using glasses or corrective lenses as usual?
How good is your eyesight for seeing things at a distance, like recognizing a friend across the street, using glasses or corrective lenses as usual?
How good is your eyesight for seeing things up close, like reading ordinary newspaper print, using glasses or corrective lenses as usual?
Frustrated When talking to Family Members
Attend Religious Service Less Often due to Hearing
Arguments with Family Members due to Hearing Problem
Hearing Difficulty when listening to TV or Radio
Please say today\'s Date. Click on START to record.
If you could here the recording, Please click on NEXT.\nElse click on START to record again.
Part of this study is concerned with people\'s memory, and ability to think about things.
How would you rate your memory at the present time?
Compared to two years ago, would you say your memory is better now, about the same, or worse now than it was then?

For this next task you will hear a set of 10 words. You will then be asked to recall as many words as you can. We have purposely made the list long so that it will be difficult for anyone to recall all the words – most people recall just a few.

 Please listen carefully as the set of words are read to you. You will only hear the words once.

 When the word list is finished, you will be asked to recall aloud as many of the words as you can, in any order.
Now please say as many words that you can recall.
For this next task, please try to count backward as quickly as you can from the number 20.
Please click on START to record your response.
Now let\'s try some subtraction of numbers.\n\n What is 100 minus 7?
A little while ago, you heard a list of words and you repeated the ones you could remember. Please tell me any of the words that you remember now.

Next I would like to ask you some questions which assess how people use numbers in everyday life.\n\n If the chance of getting a disease is 10 percent, how many people out of 1,000 would be expected to get the disease?
If 5 people all have the winning numbers in a lottery and the prize is 2 million dollars, how much will each of them get?
Let\’s say you have $200 in a savings account. The account earns 10 percent interest per year. How much would you have in the account at the end of two years?
How many different animals can you name?\n\n You will have 45 seconds. Click on START, and say the names of animals as fast as you can.
Please name as many different things that you can eat or drink as you can.\n\n You will have 45 seconds. Click on START, and say the names of things you can eat or drink as fast as you can.
How many different things can you name that are blue?\n\n You will have 45 seconds. Click on START, and say the names of things that are blue as fast as you can.

Instructions: In this task, on each screen you will be presented with several numbers that make up a series. There will be one or more empty boxes somewhere in the series. Sometimes the empty boxes will be at the end of the series, and sometimes they will be in the middle. Press the number buttons to enter the number that goes in each empty box.

 For example:
 Please enter the number that belongs in each empty box.
The answer we were looking for is 3, so the completed sequence is:
Below is another example.\n\n Please enter the number that belongs in each empty box.
The answer we were looking for is 8 because the numbers (2, 4, 6, 8) increase by 2. The completed sequence is:

You will now see six more questions like the ones you just did.

 Instructions:
 • Please enter the number that belongs in each empty box.
 • An empty box could be at the end of a series or it could be in the middle.
 • You may be asked a question with more than one empty box in the sequence.
 • The numbers might increase, like 2, 4, 6, or decrease, like 6, 4, 2.
 • Some of the items may be easy but others may be hard. Just do the best you can.
 • It is more important to answer the item correctly than to answer quickly, so take a little time to think before answering.
 • In a few cases, more than one number may be correct. Please give only one answer per box. If your answer is one of the correct answers, you will receive credit.
 • You can go on to the next item at any time by clicking “Next.”

 If you are ready to begin, please click “Next.”
Please enter the number that belongs in each empty box.

Instructions: In this next task, you will see several words on each screen, followed by a blank. Please say the word that best completes the phrase. To record your answer, press the RECORD ANSWER button.\n\n Read the example below:
Mother is to Daughter as Father is to _
Mother is to Daughter as Father is to Son
Press the RECORD ANSWER button and say the word that best completes this phrase.

Instructions:
 • You will now be asked to complete three more phrases like the example you just saw.
 • Please say the word that best completes each phrase.
 • Some of the items may be easy, but others may be hard. Just do the best you can.
 • It is more important to answer the item correctly than it is to answer quickly, so take a little time to think before answering.
 • In a few cases, more than one word could be correct. If your answer is one of the correct answers, you will receive credit.
 • You can go on to the next item at any time by clicking “Next.”

 If you are ready to begin, please click “Next.”
Please take your time to answer.
You have not submitted a response yet. Your answers are important to us. Please try to answer as best you can. If you are not willing to provide an answer, please press NEXT to continue.
You did not complete the question. Your answers are important to us. Please try to answer as best you can. If you are not willing to provide an answer, please press NEXT to continue.
Night is to Dark as Day is to _
Tomato is to Carrot as Red is to _
Two is to Duet as Three is to _
INSTRUCTIONS\n Each item in this task consists of a set of figures arranged in a pattern, formed according to certain rules.\n Look at the figures in the first example.

The question mark in the lower right corner of the box shows where a figure is missing in the pattern. You are to decide which one of the five figures under the pattern belongs where the question mark is.
The correct answer is the figure selected here.

It follows the same pattern as the other figures in the box. The figure in the bottom left is larger than the one above it but otherwise the same. In the top row, the figure at the right is the same as the one to the left of it except that it has been turned upside down. Following these rules, the missing figure should be larger than the one above it, and exactly the same size as the one to the left of it, but upside down. Therefore, the response choice selected is the correct answer.\n\n Press the NEXT button to continue.
Here is a practice item. Select the figure that completes the pattern then press NEXT. Or if you would like to read the instructions again, press the BACK button.
Now look at another problem, which is quite different from either of the previous ones.
That is correct. Going from left to right, the circles get larger, and going from top to bottom they get darker.

No, the correct response is this one. Going from left to right, the circles get larger, and going from top to bottom they get darker. Therefore the answer has to be a circle which is the largest of the three sizes, and the darkest. There are two response options that are the right size, but only one has the correct shading. The selected response is the only drawing that fits the pattern.\n\n Press the NEXT button to continue, or the BACK button to go back one page.

What is the missing figure here? If you study the pattern you will see that going from left to right there is one more line in each figure than in the one to the left of it. Going from top to bottom, the number of lines in any figure is one less than in the figure just above it. Therefore, the missing figure should have three lines. The correct answer has been selected (the three lines, slanting in the proper direction).

INSTRUCTIONS

 • You will now be asked six more questions like the ones you just did. 
 • For each problem, decide what rules the pattern follows. Choose the answer that belongs in the question mark (?) by pressing the response option.
 • Each problem has a different rule, so the patterns may seem quite different from the ones in the example items. 
 • Do not spend too much time on any one problem. 

 When you are ready, press the BEGIN button.
Each item in this task has a drawing of a flat piece of metal, like the example shown here.

Below each drawing are five objects, only one of which can be made by folding the flat piece of metal along the dotted lines. You are to select which object shows just how the piece of flat metal would look when it is folded at the dotted lines. When it is folded, no piece of metal overlaps any other piece, or is enclosed inside the object.
Now look at the example.\n\nSelect which of the five objects would be made by folding the flat piece along each of the dotted lines.
Press the object and then the NEXT button when you are ready to go on.

It follows the same pattern as the other figures in the box. The figure in the bottom left is larger than the one above it but otherwise the same. In the top row, the figure at the right is the same as the one to the left of it except that it has been turned upside down. Following these rules, the missing figure should be larger than the one above it, and exactly the same size as the one to the left of it, but upside down. Therefore, the response choice selected is the correct answer.

That is correct. Of the five objects shown, only this one could be made from the flat piece by folding it at each of the dotted lines.\n\n Press the NEXT button to continue, or the BACK button to go back one page.

No, the correct response is this one. Only it could be made from the flat piece by folding it at each of the dotted lines.\n\n Press the NEXT button to continue, or the BACK button to go back one page.

INSTRUCTIONS

 • For each item, select the object that could be made by folding the flat piece at each of the dotted lines.
 • All folds are indicated by dotted lines.
 • The solid lines show the cuts in the piece.
 • Parts are not folded inside of other parts of any objects (in other words, there is no overlapping).

 When you are ready, press the BEGIN button.

Instructions: In this task, you will see several pictures. Please say the name of the pictured object. To record your answer, press the RECORD ANSWER button. If you do not know what is pictured, just give your best guess.\n\n Please click “Next” to see an example.
What is shown in this picture? Press the RECORD ANSWER button and say the name of this object.
For example, if you see a picture of any kind of car, you would just say the word “car.”\n You can see this example below.
Please click “Next” to see another example.
What is the arrow pointing to? Press the RECORD ANSWER button and say the name of the object.

In the above example, you would say “eraser”. While the picture shows a pencil, the arrow is pointing to a specific part of this pencil– its eraser. Not all pictures will have arrows. In those cases, you are to say the word that best describes the entire picture. So in the above example, if no arrow were present, you would simply say “pencil”.

 You will now be asked to identify six more pictures. Take your time. While you do not have an unlimited amount of time to respond to each problem, it is more important to answer correctly than to answer quickly.

 Please click “Next” to begin.

In this next task, we would like to see how quickly you can respond to the words RED and GREEN.

 For the first several items, if you see RED you will press the STOP button. If you see GREEN you will press the GO button.

 Try to be accurate, but respond as quickly as you can.

For example, if you see:

 RED

 You should press the STOP button. Please do this now.

And if you see:

 GREEN

 You should press the GO button. Please do this now.
You pressed GO. Please press the STOP button.
You pressed STOP. Please press the GO button.
This first set will last about 30 seconds. Please press BEGIN when you are ready.
You have not submitted a response. Please press STOP or GO to continue to the next item.
You did not answer the previous item in the time allowed. Please press NEXT to continue to the next item.
You have not responded to the last 5 items. Please choose “Exit” to exit this task, or choose “Continue” to continue this task.

Now you will do just the REVERSE of what you have been doing. So when you see RED you will press the GO button. When you see GREEN you will press the STOP button.\n\n Try to be accurate, but answer as quickly as you can.

For example, if you see:

 RED

 Because the rules are “REVERSE,” you should press the GO button. Please do this now.

And if you see:

 GREEN

 You should press the STOP button. Please do this now.

Now we are going to mix up these two types of responses. When you see the word NORMAL, you will respond the way you did at first: RED means “STOP”, GREEN means “GO”. But when you see the word REVERSE, you will give the reverse responses: RED means “GO”, and GREEN means “STOP”.

 We will alternate between the NORMAL and the REVERSE every few trials.

 Try to be accurate, but answer as quickly as you can.

So if you see:

 RED

 You should press the STOP button. This is because the last screen said “NORMAL,” and this screen says “RED.” Please do this now.

And if you see:

 GREEN

 You should press the GO button. This is because the rules screen said “NORMAL,” and this screen says “GREEN.” Please do this now.

And if you see:

 RED

 You should press the STOP button. Please do this now.

So if you see:

 GREEN

 You should press the STOP button. This is because the last screen said “REVERSE,” and this screen says “GREEN.” Please do this now.

Or if you see:

 RED

 You should press the GO button. This is because the rules screen said “REVERSE,” and this screen says “RED.” Please do this now.

Or if you see:

 RED

 You should press the GO button. Please do this now.
Now, please practice a few times on your own.
We are now ready to begin. This will take about one minute. Please press BEGIN when you are ready.
How often do you check your e-mail?
Other than e-mail, how often do you use the internet (for example, to read news, check weather, make purchases, search for information, make travel reservations, etc.)?
Now we would like to ask you some questions regarding your thoughts about participating in this study using the tablet.
Did you read the User Manual before handling the tablet?
The User Manual was easy for me to understand
Did you have any trouble turning on the tablet?
Did you need any help in using the tablet?
Did you contact the study help line for assistance?
The touch screen was easy to use.
The words and images on the tablet were easy to see and read.
Picking a specific answer to a survey question was easy for me.
I enjoyed completing the interview on the tablet.
Using the tablet was a stressful experience for me.
Now, we have just a few final questions for you.
How much did you enjoy this interview?
How tired did you feel while completing this interview?
Were you doing any other activities while completing this interview, for example, checking email or doing household chores?
We hear a lot of talk these days about liberals and conservatives. Where would you place yourself: would you say you are generally liberal, conservative, or something in between?
What is your favorite type of TV show?
What is the name of your favorite TV show?

You have now completed the cognitive tasks.

 Thank you for your participation!

 Please refer to the User Manual for instructions on how to turn off the tablet, and return the tablet to AIR.
Instruction: Type in the name and press DONE.
Click on arrow to enter value in the second box.
Which of the following types of technology do you use regularly?
Mobile phone other than a smartphone

INSTRUCTIONS


 This task contains words for you to define. The items are multiple choice - select the best response for each word.
A vacuum is a space containing
A diagram is a kind of
Which of these is not a measuring device?
A purpose of lubrication is to
A barometer is used to measure
The word list will now be repeated.
